text: David took the golden shields which Hadadezer’s servants had carried and brought them to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Tibhath and Kun, Hadadezer’s cities, David took a great deal of bronze. (Solomon used it to make the big bronze basin called “The Sea,” the pillars, and other bronze items.)
speaker: Narrator

text: When King Tou of Hamath heard that David had defeated the entire army of King Hadadezer of Zobah,
speaker: Narrator

text: he sent his son Hadoram to King David to extend his best wishes and to pronounce a blessing on him for his victory over Hadadezer, for Tou had been at war with Hadadezer. He also sent various items made of gold, silver, and bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: King David dedicated these things to the Lord, along with the silver and gold which he had carried off from all the nations, including Edom, Moab, the Ammonites, the Philistines, and Amalek.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abishai son of Zeruiah killed 18,000 Edomites in the Valley of Salt.
speaker: Narrator

text: He placed garrisons in Edom, and all the Edomites became David’s subjects. The Lord protected David wherever he campaigned.
speaker: Narrator

text: David reigned over all Israel; he guaranteed justice for all his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab son of Zeruiah was commanding general of the army; Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was secretary;
speaker: Narrator

text: Zadok son of Ahitub and Abimelech son of Abiathar were priests; Shavsha was scribe;
speaker: Narrator

text: Benaiah son of Jehoiada supervised the Kerethites and Pelethites; and David’s sons were the king’s leading officials.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later King Nahash of the Ammonites died and his son succeeded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said, “I will express my loyalty to Hanun son of Nahash, for his father was loyal to me.” So David sent messengers to express his sympathy over his father’s death. When David’s servants entered Ammonite territory to visit Hanun and express the king’s sympathy,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Ammonite officials said to Hanun, “Do you really think David is trying to honor your father by sending these messengers to express his sympathy? No, his servants have come to you so they can get information and spy out the land!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hanun seized David’s servants and shaved their beards off. He cut off the lower part of their robes so that their buttocks were exposed and then sent them away.
speaker: Narrator

text: People came and told David what had happened to the men, so he sent messengers to meet them, for the men were thoroughly humiliated. The king said, “Stay in Jericho until your beards grow again; then you may come back.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Ammonites realized that David was disgusted with them, Hanun and the Ammonites sent 1,000 talents of silver to hire chariots and charioteers from Aram Naharaim, Aram Maacah, and Zobah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They hired 32,000 chariots, along with the king of Maacah and his army, who came and camped in front of Medeba. The Ammonites also assembled from their cities and marched out to do battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David heard the news, he sent Joab and the entire army to meet them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ammonites marched out and were deployed for battle at the entrance to the city, while the kings who had come were by themselves in the field.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joab saw that the battle would be fought on two fronts, he chose some of Israel’s best men and deployed them against the Arameans.
speaker: Narrator

text: He put his brother Abishai in charge of the rest of the army and they were deployed against the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab said, “If the Arameans start to overpower me, you come to my rescue. If the Ammonites start to overpower you, I will come to your rescue.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be strong! Let’s fight bravely for the sake of our people and the cities of our God! The Lord will do what he decides is best!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Joab and his men marched toward the Arameans to do battle, and they fled before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Ammonites saw the Arameans flee, they fled before Joab’s brother Abishai and withdrew into the city. Joab went back to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Arameans realized they had been defeated by Israel, they sent for reinforcements from beyond the Euphrates River, led by Shophach the commanding general of Hadadezer’s army.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David was informed, he gathered all Israel, crossed the Jordan River, and marched against them. David deployed his army against the Arameans for battle and they fought against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Arameans fled before Israel. David killed 7,000 Aramean charioteers and 40,000 infantrymen; he also killed Shophach the commanding general.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Hadadezer’s subjects saw they were defeated by Israel, they made peace with David and became his subjects. The Arameans were no longer willing to help the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the spring, at the time when kings normally conduct wars, Joab led the army into battle and devastated the land of the Ammonites. He went and besieged Rabbah, while David stayed in Jerusalem. Joab defeated Rabbah and tore it down.
speaker: Narrator

text: David took the crown from the head of their king and wore it (its weight was a talent of gold and it was set with precious stones). He took a large amount of plunder from the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: He removed the city’s residents and made them labor with saws, iron picks, and axes. This was his policy with all the Ammonite cities. Then David and all the army returned to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later there was a battle with the Philistines in Gezer. At that time Sibbekai the Hushathite killed Sippai, one of the descendants of the Rephaim, and the Philistines were subdued.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was another battle with the Philistines in which Elhanan son of Jair the Bethlehemite killed the brother of Goliath the Gittite, whose spear had a shaft as big as the crossbeam of a weaver’s loom.
speaker: Narrator

text: In a battle in Gath there was a large man who had six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot—twenty-four in all! He too was a descendant of Rapha.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he taunted Israel, Jonathan son of Shimea, David’s brother, killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the descendants of Rapha who lived in Gath; they were killed by the hand of David and his soldiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: An adversary opposed Israel, inciting David to count how many warriors Israel had.
speaker: Narrator

text: David told Joab and the leaders of the army, “Go, count the number of warriors from Beer Sheba to Dan. Then bring back a report to me so I may know how many we have.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab replied, “May the Lord make his army a hundred times larger! My master, O king, do not all of them serve my master? Why does my master want to do this? Why bring judgment on Israel?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king’s edict stood, despite Joab’s objections. So Joab left and traveled throughout Israel before returning to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab reported to David the number of warriors. In all Israel there were 1,100,000 sword-wielding soldiers; Judah alone had 470,000 sword-wielding soldiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Joab did not number Levi and Benjamin, for the king’s edict disgusted him.
speaker: Narrator

text: God was also offended by it, so he attacked Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to God, “I have sinned greatly by doing this! Now, please remove the guilt of your servant, for I have acted very foolishly.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord told Gad, David’s prophet,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go, tell David, ‘This is what the Lord says: “I am offering you three forms of judgment from which to choose. Pick one of them.”’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Gad went to David and told him, “This is what the Lord says: ‘Pick one of these:
speaker: Narrator

text: three years of famine, or three months being chased by your enemies and struck down by their swords, or three days being struck down by the Lord, during which a plague will invade the land and the angel of the Lord will destroy throughout Israel’s territory.’ Now, decide what I should tell the one who sent me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Gad, “I am very upset! I prefer to be attacked by the Lord, for his mercy is very great; I do not want to be attacked by men!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord sent a plague through Israel, and 70,000 Israelite men died.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God sent an angel to ravage Jerusalem. As he was doing so, the Lord watched and relented from his judgment. He told the angel who was destroying, “That’s enough! Stop now!”
Now the angel of the Lord was standing near the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite.
speaker: Narrator

text: David looked up and saw the angel of the Lord standing between the earth and sky with his sword drawn and in his hand, stretched out over Jerusalem. David and the leaders, covered with sackcloth, threw themselves down with their faces to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to God, “Was I not the one who decided to number the army? I am the one who sinned and committed this awful deed! As for these sheep—what have they done? O Lord my God, attack me and my family, but remove the plague from your people!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the angel of the Lord told Gad to instruct David to go up and build an altar for the Lord on the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David went up as Gad instructed him to do in the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Ornan was threshing wheat, he turned and saw the messenger, and he and his four sons hid themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David came to Ornan, Ornan looked and saw David; he came out from the threshing floor and bowed to David with his face to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Ornan, “Sell me the threshing floor so I can build on it an altar for the Lord—I’ll pay top price—so that the plague may be removed from the people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ornan told David, “You can have it! My master, the king, may do what he wants. Look, I am giving you the oxen for burnt sacrifices, the threshing sledges for wood, and the wheat for an offering. I give it all to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: King David replied to Ornan, “No, I insist on buying it for top price. I will not offer to the Lord what belongs to you or offer a burnt sacrifice that cost me nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David bought the place from Ornan for 600 pieces of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: David built there an altar to the Lord and offered burnt sacrifices and peace offerings. He called out to the Lord, and the Lord responded by sending fire from the sky and consuming the burnt sacrifice on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord ordered the messenger to put his sword back into its sheath.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time, when David saw that the Lord responded to him at the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite, he sacrificed there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Lord’s tabernacle (which Moses had made in the wilderness) and the altar for burnt sacrifices were at that time at the worship center in Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: But David could not go before it to seek God’s will, for he was afraid of the sword of the angel of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: David then said, “This is the place where the temple of the Lord God will be, along with the altar for burnt sacrifices for Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David ordered the resident foreigners in the land of Israel to be called together. He appointed some of them to be stonecutters to chisel stones for the building of God’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: David supplied a large amount of iron for the nails of the doors of the gates and for braces, more bronze than could be weighed,
speaker: Narrator

text: and more cedar logs than could be counted. (The Sidonians and Tyrians had brought a large amount of cedar logs to David.)
speaker: Narrator

text: David said, “My son Solomon is just an inexperienced young man, and the temple to be built for the Lord must be especially magnificent so it will become famous and be considered splendid by all the nations. Therefore I will make preparations for its construction.” So David made extensive preparations before he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: He summoned his son Solomon and charged him to build a temple for the Lord God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Solomon: “My son, I really wanted to build a temple to honor the Lord my God.
speaker: Narrator

text: But this was the Lord’s message to me: ‘You have spilled a great deal of blood and fought many battles. You must not build a temple to honor me, for you have spilled a great deal of blood on the ground before me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, you will have a son, who will be a peaceful man. I will give him rest from all his enemies on every side. Indeed, Solomon will be his name; I will give Israel peace and quiet during his reign.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will build a temple to honor me; he will become my son, and I will become his father. I will grant to his dynasty permanent rule over Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now, my son, may the Lord be with you! May you succeed and build a temple for the Lord your God, just as he announced you would.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only may the Lord give you insight and understanding when he places you in charge of Israel, so you may obey the law of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you will succeed, if you carefully obey the rules and regulations which the Lord ordered Moses to give to Israel. Be strong and brave! Don’t be afraid and don’t panic!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, look, I have made every effort to supply what is needed to build the Lord’s temple. I have stored up 100,000 talents of gold, 1,000,000 talents of silver, and so much bronze and iron it cannot be weighed, as well as wood and stones. Feel free to add more!
speaker: Narrator

text: You also have available many workers, including stonecutters, masons, carpenters, and an innumerable array of workers who are skilled
speaker: Narrator

text: in using gold, silver, bronze, and iron. Get up and begin the work! May the Lord be with you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: David ordered all the officials of Israel to support his son Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told them, “The Lord your God is with you! He has made you secure on every side, for he handed over to me the inhabitants of the region and the region is subdued before the Lord and his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now seek the Lord your God wholeheartedly and with your entire being! Get up and build the sanctuary of the Lord God! Then you can bring the ark of the Lord’s covenant and the holy items dedicated to God’s service into the temple that is built to honor the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When David was old and approaching the end of his life, he made his son Solomon king over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David assembled all the leaders of Israel, along with the priests and the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites who were thirty years old and up were counted; there were 38,000 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said, “Of these, 24,000 are to direct the work of the Lord’s temple; 6,000 are to be officials and judges;
speaker: Narrator

text: 4,000 are to be gatekeepers; and 4,000 are to praise the Lord with the instruments I supplied for worship.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David divided them into groups corresponding to the sons of Levi: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Gershonites included Ladan and Shimei.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Ladan: Jehiel the oldest, Zetham, and Joel—three in all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Shimei: Shelomoth, Haziel, and Haran—three in all.
These were the leaders of the family of Ladan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Shimei: Jahath, Zina, Jeush, and Beriah. These were Shimei’s sons—four in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jahath was the oldest and Zizah the second oldest. Jeush and Beriah did not have many sons, so they were considered one family with one responsibility.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Kohath: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel—four in all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Amram: Aaron and Moses.
Aaron and his descendants were chosen on a permanent basis to consecrate the most holy items, to offer sacrifices before the Lord, to serve him, and to praise his name.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Moses the man of God were considered Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Moses: Gershom and Eliezer.
speaker: Narrator

text: The son of Gershom: Shebuel the oldest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The son of Eliezer was Rehabiah, the oldest. Eliezer had no other sons, but Rehabiah had many descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: The son of Izhar: Shelomith the oldest.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Hebron: Jeriah the oldest, Amariah the second, Jahaziel the third, and Jekameam the fourth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Uzziel: Micah the oldest, and Isshiah the second.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Merari: Mahli and Mushi.
The sons of Mahli: Eleazar and Kish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eleazar died without having sons; he had only daughters. The sons of Kish, their cousins, married them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Mushi: Mahli, Eder, and Jeremoth—three in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the descendants of Levi according to their families, that is, the leaders of families as counted and individually listed who carried out assigned tasks in the Lord’s temple and were twenty years old and up.
speaker: Narrator

text: For David said, “The Lord God of Israel has given his people rest and has permanently settled in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Levites no longer need to carry the tabernacle or any of the items used in its service.”
speaker: Narrator

text: According to David’s final instructions, the Levites twenty years old or older were counted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their job was to help Aaron’s descendants in the service of the Lord’s temple. They were to take care of the courtyards, the rooms, ceremonial purification of all holy items, and other jobs related to the service of God’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also took care of the bread that is displayed, the flour for offerings, the unleavened wafers, the round cakes, the mixing, and all the measuring.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also stood in a designated place every morning and offered thanks and praise to the Lord. They also did this in the evening
speaker: Narrator

text: and whenever burnt sacrifices were offered to the Lord on the Sabbath and at new moon festivals and assemblies. A designated number were to serve before the Lord regularly in accordance with regulations.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were in charge of the meeting tent and the Holy Place, and helped their relatives, the descendants of Aaron, in the service of the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The divisions of Aaron’s descendants were as follows:
The sons of Aaron: Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nadab and Abihu died before their father did; they had no sons. Eleazar and Ithamar served as priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: David, Zadok (a descendant of Eleazar), and Ahimelech (a descendant of Ithamar) divided them into groups to carry out their assigned responsibilities.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Eleazar had more leaders than the descendants of Ithamar, so they divided them up accordingly; the descendants of Eleazar had sixteen leaders, while the descendants of Ithamar had eight.
speaker: Narrator

text: They divided them by lots, for there were officials of the Holy Place and officials designated by God among the descendants of both Eleazar and Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The scribe Shemaiah son of Nethanel, a Levite, wrote down their names before the king, the officials, Zadok the priest, Ahimelech son of Abiathar, and the leaders of the priestly and Levite families. One family was drawn by lot from Eleazar, and then the next from Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The first lot went to Jehoiarib,
the second to Jedaiah,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the third to Harim,
the fourth to Seorim,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the fifth to Malkijah,
the sixth to Mijamin,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the seventh to Hakkoz,
the eighth to Abijah,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the ninth to Jeshua,
the tenth to Shecaniah,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the eleventh to Eliashib,
the twelfth to Jakim,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the thirteenth to Huppah,
the fourteenth to Jeshebeab,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the fifteenth to Bilgah,
the sixteenth to Immer,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the seventeenth to Hezir,
the eighteenth to Happizzez,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the nineteenth to Pethahiah,
the twentieth to Jehezkel,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the twenty-first to Jakin,
the twenty-second to Gamul,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the twenty-third to Delaiah,
the twenty-fourth to Maaziah.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the order in which they carried out their assigned responsibilities when they entered the Lord’s temple, according to the regulations given them by their ancestor Aaron, just as the Lord God of Israel had instructed him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The rest of the Levites included:
Shubael from the sons of Amram,
Jehdeiah from the sons of Shubael,
speaker: Narrator

text: the firstborn Isshiah from Rehabiah and the sons of Rehabiah,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shelomoth from the Izharites,
Jahath from the sons of Shelomoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Hebron: Jeriah, Amariah the second, Jahaziel the third, and Jekameam the fourth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The son of Uzziel: Micah;
Shamir from the sons of Micah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The brother of Micah: Isshiah.
Zechariah from the sons of Isshiah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Merari: Mahli and Mushi.
The son of Jaaziah: Beno.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Merari, from Jaaziah: Beno, Shoham, Zaccur, and Ibri.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Mahli: Eleazar, who had no sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: From Kish: Jerahmeel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Mushi: Mahli, Eder, and Jerimoth.
These were the Levites, listed by their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: Like their relatives, the descendants of Aaron, they also cast lots before King David, Zadok, Ahimelech, the leaders of families, the priests, and the Levites. The families of the oldest son cast lots along with those of the youngest.
speaker: Narrator

text: David and the army officers selected some of the sons of Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun to prophesy as they played stringed instruments and cymbals. The following men were assigned this responsibility:
speaker: Narrator

text: From the sons of Asaph: Zaccur, Joseph, Nethaniah, and Asarelah. The sons of Asaph were supervised by Asaph, who prophesied under the king’s supervision.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the sons of Jeduthun: Gedaliah, Zeri, Jeshaiah, Hashabiah, and Mattithiah—six in all, under supervision of their father Jeduthun, who prophesied as he played a harp, giving thanks and praise to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the sons of Heman: Bukkiah, Mattaniah, Uzziel, Shebuel, Jerimoth, Hananiah, Hanani, Eliathah, Giddalti, Romamti-Ezer, Joshbekashah, Mallothi, Hothir, and Mahazioth.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these were the sons of Heman, the king’s prophet. God had promised him these sons in order to make him prestigious. God gave Heman fourteen sons and three daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these were under the supervision of their fathers; they were musicians in the Lord’s temple, playing cymbals and stringed instruments as they served in God’s temple. Asaph, Jeduthun, and Heman were under the supervision of the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: They and their relatives, all of them skilled and trained to make music to the Lord, numbered 288.
speaker: Narrator

text: They cast lots to determine their responsibilities—oldest as well as youngest, teacher as well as student.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The first lot went to Asaph’s son Joseph and his relatives and sons—twelve in all,
the second to Gedaliah and his relatives and sons—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the third to Zaccur and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the fourth to Izri and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the fifth to Nethaniah and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the sixth to Bukkiah and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the seventh to Jesharelah and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the eighth to Jeshaiah and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the ninth to Mattaniah and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the tenth to Shimei and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the eleventh to Azarel and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the twelfth to Hashabiah and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the thirteenth to Shubael and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the fourteenth to Mattithiah and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the fifteenth to Jerimoth and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the sixteenth to Hananiah and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the seventeenth to Joshbekashah and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the eighteenth to Hanani and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the nineteenth to Mallothi and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the twentieth to Eliathah and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the twenty-first to Hothir and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the twenty-second to Giddalti and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the twenty-third to Mahazioth and his sons and relatives—twelve in all,
speaker: Narrator

text: the twenty-fourth to Romamti-Ezer and his sons and relatives—twelve in all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The divisions of the gatekeepers:
From the Korahites: Meshelemiah, son of Kore, one of the sons of Asaph.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Meshelemiah’s sons:
The firstborn Zechariah, the second Jediael, the third Zebadiah, the fourth Jathniel,
speaker: Narrator

text: the fifth Elam, the sixth Jehohanan, and the seventh Elihoenai.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Obed-Edom’s sons:
The firstborn Shemaiah, the second Jehozabad, the third Joah, the fourth Sakar, the fifth Nethanel,
speaker: Narrator

text: the sixth Ammiel, the seventh Issachar, and the eighth Peullethai. (Indeed, God blessed Obed-Edom.)
speaker: Narrator

text: His son Shemaiah also had sons, who were leaders of their families, for they were highly respected.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Shemaiah:
Othni, Rephael, Obed, and Elzabad. His relatives Elihu and Semakiah were also respected.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these were the descendants of Obed-Edom. They and their sons and relatives were respected men, capable of doing their responsibilities. There were sixty-two of them related to Obed-Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meshelemiah had sons and relatives who were respected—eighteen in all.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hosah, one of the descendants of Merari, had sons:
The firstborn Shimri (he was not actually the firstborn, but his father gave him that status),
speaker: Narrator

text: the second Hilkiah, the third Tebaliah, and the fourth Zechariah. All Hosah’s sons and relatives numbered thirteen.
speaker: Narrator

text: These divisions of the gatekeepers, corresponding to their leaders, had assigned responsibilities, like their relatives, as they served in the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: They cast lots, both young and old, according to their families, to determine which gate they would be responsible for.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lot for the east gate went to Shelemiah. They then cast lots for his son Zechariah, a wise adviser, and the lot for the north gate went to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Obed-Edom was assigned the south gate, and his sons were assigned the storehouses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shuppim and Hosah were assigned the west gate, along with the Shalleketh gate on the upper road. One guard was adjacent to another.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each day there were six Levites posted on the east, four on the north, and four on the south. At the storehouses they were posted in pairs.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the court on the west there were four posted on the road and two at the court.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the divisions of the gatekeepers who were descendants of Korah and Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their fellow Levites were in charge of the storehouses in God’s temple and the storehouses containing consecrated items.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Ladan, who were descended from Gershon through Ladan and were leaders of the families of Ladan the Gershonite, included Jehieli
speaker: Narrator

text: and the sons of Jehieli, Zetham and his brother Joel. They were in charge of the storehouses in the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the Amramites, Izharites, Hebronites, and Uzzielites:
speaker: Narrator

text: Shebuel son of Gershom, the son of Moses, was the supervisor of the storehouses.
speaker: Narrator

text: His relatives through Eliezer included: Rehabiah his son, Jeshaiah his son, Joram his son, Zikri his son, and Shelomith his son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shelomith and his relatives were in charge of all the storehouses containing the consecrated items dedicated by King David, the family leaders who led units of a thousand and a hundred, and the army officers.
speaker: Narrator

text: They had dedicated some of the plunder taken in battles to be used for repairs on the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were also in charge of everything dedicated by Samuel the prophet, Saul son of Kish, Abner son of Ner, and Joab son of Zeruiah; Shelomith and his relatives were in charge of everything that had been dedicated.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the Izharites: Kenaniah and his sons were given responsibilities outside the temple as officers and judges over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the Hebronites: Hashabiah and his relatives, 1,700 respected men, were assigned responsibilities in Israel west of the Jordan; they did the Lord’s work and the king’s service.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the Hebronites: Jeriah was the leader of the Hebronites according to the genealogical records. In the fortieth year of David’s reign, they examined the records and discovered there were highly respected men in Jazer in Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeriah had 2,700 relatives who were respected family leaders. King David placed them in charge of the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh; they took care of all matters pertaining to God and the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: What follows is a list of Israelite family leaders and commanders of units of a thousand and a hundred, as well as their officers who served the king in various matters. Each division was assigned to serve for one month during the year; each consisted of 24,000 troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jashobeam son of Zabdiel was in charge of the first division, which was assigned the first month. His division consisted of 24,000 troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was a descendant of Perez; he was in charge of all the army officers for the first month.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dodai the Ahohite was in charge of the division assigned the second month; Mikloth was the next in rank. His division consisted of 24,000 troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: The third army commander, assigned the third month, was Benaiah son of Jehoiada the priest. He was the leader of his division, which consisted of 24,000 troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: Benaiah was the leader of the thirty warriors and his division; his son was Ammizabad.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fourth, assigned the fourth month, was Asahel, brother of Joab; his son Zebadiah succeeded him. His division consisted of 24,000 troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fifth, assigned the fifth month, was the commander Shamhuth the Izrahite. His division consisted of 24,000 troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sixth, assigned the sixth month, was Ira son of Ikkesh the Tekoite. His division consisted of 24,000 troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seventh, assigned the seventh month, was Helez the Pelonite, an Ephraimite. His division consisted of 24,000 troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eighth, assigned the eighth month, was Sibbekai the Hushathite, a Zerahite. His division consisted of 24,000 troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ninth, assigned the ninth month, was Abiezer the Anathothite, a Benjaminite. His division consisted of 24,000 troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tenth, assigned the tenth month, was Maharai the Netophathite, a Zerahite. His division consisted of 24,000 troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eleventh, assigned the eleventh month, was Benaiah the Pirathonite, an Ephraimite. His division consisted of 24,000 troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: The twelfth, assigned the twelfth month, was Heldai the Netophathite, a descendant of Othniel. His division consisted of 24,000 troops.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The officers of the Israelite tribes:
Eliezer son of Zikri was the leader of the Reubenites,
Shephatiah son of Maacah led the Simeonites,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hashabiah son of Kemuel led the Levites,
Zadok led the descendants of Aaron,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Elihu, a brother of David, led Judah,
Omri son of Michael led Issachar,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ishmaiah son of Obadiah led Zebulun,
Jerimoth son of Azriel led Naphtali,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hoshea son of Azaziah led the Ephraimites,
Joel son of Pedaiah led the half-tribe of Manasseh,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Iddo son of Zechariah led the half-tribe of Manasseh in Gilead,
Jaasiel son of Abner led Benjamin,
speaker: Narrator

text:
Azarel son of Jeroham led Dan.
These were the commanders of the Israelite tribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: David did not count the males twenty years old and under, for the Lord had promised to make Israel as numerous as the stars in the sky.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab son of Zeruiah started to count the men but did not finish. God was angry with Israel because of this, so the number was not recorded in the scroll called The Annals of King David.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Azmaveth son of Adiel was in charge of the king’s storehouses;
Jonathan son of Uzziah was in charge of the storehouses in the field, in the cities, in the towns, and in the towers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ezri son of Kelub was in charge of the field workers who farmed the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shimei the Ramathite was in charge of the vineyards;
Zabdi the Shiphmite was in charge of the wine stored in the vineyards.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Baal Hanan the Gederite was in charge of the olive and sycamore trees in the foothills;
Joash was in charge of the storehouses of olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shitrai the Sharonite was in charge of the cattle grazing in Sharon;
Shaphat son of Adlai was in charge of the cattle in the valleys.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Obil the Ishmaelite was in charge of the camels;
Jehdeiah the Meronothite was in charge of the donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jaziz the Hagrite was in charge of the sheep.
All these were the officials in charge of King David’s property.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jonathan, David’s uncle, was a wise adviser and scribe;
Jehiel son of Hacmoni cared for the king’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ahithophel was the king’s adviser;
Hushai the Arkite was the king’s confidant.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ahithophel was succeeded by Jehoiada son of Benaiah and by Abiathar.
Joab was the commanding general of the king’s army.
speaker: Narrator

text: David assembled in Jerusalem all the officials of Israel, including the commanders of the tribes, the commanders of the army divisions that served the king, the commanders of units of a thousand and a hundred, the officials who were in charge of all the property and livestock of the king and his sons, the eunuchs, and the warriors, including the most skilled of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: King David rose to his feet and said: “Listen to me, my brothers and my people. I wanted to build a temple where the ark of the Lord’s covenant could be placed as a footstool for our God. I have made the preparations for building it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But God said to me, ‘You must not build a temple to honor me, for you are a warrior and have spilled blood.’
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord God of Israel chose me out of my father’s entire family to become king over Israel and have a permanent dynasty. Indeed, he chose Judah as leader, and my father’s family within Judah, and then he picked me out from among my father’s sons and made me king over all Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: From all the many sons the Lord has given me, he chose Solomon my son to rule on his behalf over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, ‘Solomon your son is the one who will build my temple and my courts, for I have chosen him to become my son and I will become his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will establish his kingdom permanently, if he remains committed to obeying my commands and regulations, as you are doing this day.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, in the sight of all Israel, the Lord’s assembly, and in the hearing of our God, I say this: Carefully observe all the commands of the Lord your God, so that you may possess this good land and may leave it as a permanent inheritance for your children after you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And you, Solomon my son, obey the God of your father and serve him with a submissive attitude and a willing spirit, for the Lord examines all minds and understands every motive of one’s thoughts. If you seek him, he will let you find him, but if you abandon him, he will reject you permanently.
speaker: Narrator

text: Realize now that the Lord has chosen you to build a temple as his sanctuary. Be strong and do it!”
speaker: Narrator

text: David gave to his son Solomon the blueprints for the temple porch, its buildings, its treasuries, its upper areas, its inner rooms, and the room for atonement.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave him the blueprints of all he envisioned for the courts of the Lord’s temple, all the surrounding rooms, the storehouses of God’s temple, and the storehouses for the holy items.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave him the regulations for the divisions of priests and Levites, for all the assigned responsibilities within the Lord’s temple, and for all the items used in the service of the Lord’s temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: He gave him the prescribed weight for all the gold items to be used in various types of service in the Lord’s temple, for all the silver items to be used in various types of service,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the gold lampstands and their gold lamps, including the weight of each lampstand and its lamps, for the silver lampstands, including the weight of each lampstand and its lamps, according to the prescribed use of each lampstand,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the gold used in the display tables, including the amount to be used in each table, for the silver to be used in the silver tables,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the pure gold used for the meat forks, bowls, and jars, for the small gold bowls, including the weight for each bowl, for the small silver bowls, including the weight for each bowl,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and for the refined gold of the incense altar.
He gave him the blueprint for the seat of the gold cherubim that spread their wings and provide shelter for the ark of the Lord’s covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said, “All this I put in writing as the Lord directed me and gave me insight regarding the details of the blueprints.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to his son Solomon: “Be strong and brave! Do it! Don’t be afraid and don’t panic! For the Lord God, my God, is with you. He will not leave you or abandon you before all the work for the service of the Lord’s temple is finished.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here are the divisions of the priests and Levites who will perform all the service of God’s temple. All the willing and skilled men are ready to assist you in all the work and perform their service. The officials and all the people are ready to follow your instructions.”
speaker: Narrator

text: King David said to the entire assembly: “My son Solomon, the one whom God has chosen, is just an inexperienced young man, and the task is great, for this palace is not for man, but for the Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I have made every effort to provide what is needed for the temple of my God, including the gold, silver, bronze, iron, wood, as well as a large amount of onyx, settings of antimony and other stones, all kinds of precious stones, and alabaster.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, to show my commitment to the temple of my God, I donate my personal treasure of gold and silver to the temple of my God, in addition to all that I have already supplied for this holy temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: This includes 3,000 talents of gold from Ophir and 7,000 talents of refined silver for overlaying the walls of the buildings,
speaker: Narrator

text: for gold and silver items, and for all the work of the craftsmen. Who else wants to contribute to the Lord today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The leaders of the families, the leaders of the Israelite tribes, the commanders of units of a thousand and a hundred, and the supervisors of the king’s work contributed willingly.
speaker: Narrator

text: They donated for the service of God’s temple 5,000 talents and 10,000 darics of gold, 10,000 talents of silver, 18,000 talents of bronze, and 100,000 talents of iron.
speaker: Narrator

text: All who possessed precious stones donated them to the treasury of the Lord’s temple, which was under the supervision of Jehiel the Gershonite.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people were delighted with their donations, for they contributed to the Lord with a willing attitude; King David was also very happy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David praised the Lord before the entire assembly:
“O Lord God of our father Israel, you deserve praise forevermore!
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord, you are great, mighty, majestic, magnificent, glorious, and sovereign over all the sky and earth! You, Lord, have dominion and exalt yourself as the ruler of all.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are the source of wealth and honor; you rule over all. You possess strength and might to magnify and give strength to all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, our God, we give thanks to you and praise your majestic name!
speaker: Narrator

text: “But who am I and who are my people, that we should be in a position to contribute this much? Indeed, everything comes from you, and we have simply given back to you what is yours.
speaker: Narrator

text: For we are resident foreigners and temporary settlers in your presence, as all our ancestors were; our days are like a shadow on the earth, without security.
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord our God, all this wealth, which we have collected to build a temple for you to honor your holy name, comes from you; it all belongs to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I know, my God, that you examine thoughts and are pleased with integrity. With pure motives I contribute all this; and now I look with joy as your people who have gathered here contribute to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord God of our ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, always maintain these motives of your people and keep them devoted to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Make my son Solomon willing to obey your commands, rules, and regulations, and to complete building the palace for which I have made preparations.”
speaker: Narrator

text: David told the entire assembly: “Praise the Lord your God!” So the entire assembly praised the Lord God of their ancestors; they bowed down and stretched out flat on the ground before the Lord and the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day they made sacrifices and offered burnt sacrifices to the Lord (1,000 bulls, 1,000 rams, 1,000 lambs), along with their accompanying drink offerings and many other sacrifices for all Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They held a feast before the Lord that day and celebrated.
Then they designated Solomon, David’s son, as king a second time; before the Lord they anointed him as ruler and Zadok as priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon sat on the Lord’s throne as king in place of his father David; he was successful and all Israel was loyal to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the officers and warriors, as well as all of King David’s sons, pledged their allegiance to King Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord greatly magnified Solomon before all Israel and bestowed on him greater majesty than any king of Israel before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: David son of Jesse reigned over all Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He reigned over Israel forty years; he reigned in Hebron seven years and in Jerusalem thirty-three years.
speaker: Narrator

text: He died at a good old age, having enjoyed long life, wealth, and honor. His son Solomon succeeded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: King David’s accomplishments, from start to finish, are recorded in the Annals of Samuel the prophet, the Annals of Nathan the prophet, and the Annals of Gad the prophet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Recorded there are all the facts about his reign and accomplishments, and an account of the events that involved him, Israel, and all the neighboring kingdoms.
speaker: Narrator
